On Wed, 28 Jul 2004, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> "Ultimate" just means "last". As in, once you reduce the number of tests
> against a live database to a handful that run in 20 seconds, there's no
> need to go any further.

I did that on my last project. That was still more than 75 tests, which
had potential interactions with each other. It's much easier to rollback
transactions than, when a test fails, to reload a database and run an
individual test against it just to see if it was a real failure or an
interaction.

> And I disagree: you /can/ get rid of all the tests against the database
> for a given application, as long as you move the database integration to
> a separate project, write it once, and use it throughout the enterprise.

Well, that might work for you, but the freezing of that part of the
system and loss of ability to refactor would kill me. I don't see a
database table definition as any different from code to generate an HTML
form; it's all part of the application, and it all changes and moves
around as necessary. This means I not infrequently move code from the
database to Java or vice versa, just as I would move code from one class
to another.

cjs
